Fourier analysis

Let C0(R)={F ⁣:R→C | F is continuous and F(ξ)→0 as ξ→±∞}C_0\p{\R} = \set{\func{F}{\R}{\C} \st F \text{ is continuous and } F\p{\xi} \to 0 \text{ as } \xi \to \pm\infty}C0​(R)={F:R→C∣F is continuous and F(ξ)→0 as ξ→±∞}; this is a Banach space under the supremum norm. Additionally, let

X={ξ↦∫Reiξxf(x) dx | f∈L1(R)}.X = \set{\xi \mapsto \int_\R e^{i\xi x} f\p{x} \,\diff{x} \st f \in L^1\p{\R}}.X={ξ↦∫R​eiξxf(x)dx∣∣​f∈L1(R)}.

Show the following three properties of XXX:

  1. XXX is a subset of C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R).
  2. XXX is a dense subset of C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R).
  3. X≠C0(R)X \neq C_0\p{\R}X=C0​(R).
Solution.

  1. Write f^(ξ)=∫Reiξxf(x) dx\hat{f}\p{\xi} = \int_\R e^{i\xi x} f\p{x} \,\diff{x}f^​(ξ)=∫R​eiξxf(x)dx. Then if xin→ξxi_n \to \xixin​→ξ in R\RR, we have

    ∣f^(ξn)−f^(ξ)∣≤∫R∣f(x)∣∣eiξnx−eiξx∣ dx.\abs{\hat{f}\p{\xi_n} - \hat{f}\p{\xi}} \leq \int_\R \abs{f\p{x}}\abs{e^{i\xi_nx} - e^{i\xi x}} \,\diff{x}.∣∣​f^​(ξn​)−f^​(ξ)∣∣​≤∫R​∣f(x)∣∣∣​eiξn​x−eiξx∣∣​dx.

    The integrand is bounded by 2∣f(x)∣∈L1(R)2\abs{f\p{x}} \in L^1\p{\R}2∣f(x)∣∈L1(R) by assumption, so we may apply dominated convergence and continuity of eiξxe^{i\xi x}eiξx to see that f^∈C(R)\hat{f} \in C\p{\R}f^​∈C(R).

    Next, observe

    f^(ξ)=−eπi∫Reiξxf(x) dx=−∫Reiξ(x+πξ)f(x) dx=−∫Reiξxf(x−πξ) dx(x↦x+πξ)  ⟹  2f^(ξ)=∫Reiξx(f(x)−f(x−πξ)) dx  ⟹  ∣f^(ξ)∣≤12∥f−f( ⋅ −πξ)∥L1.\begin{aligned} \hat{f}\p{\xi} &= -e^{\pi i} \int_\R e^{i\xi x} f\p{x} \,\diff{x} \\ &= -\int_\R e^{i\xi\p{x + \frac{\pi}{\xi}}} f\p{x} \,\diff{x} \\ &= -\int_\R e^{i\xi x} f\p{x - \frac{\pi}{\xi}} \,\diff{x} && \p{x \mapsto x + \frac{\pi}{\xi}} \\ \implies 2\hat{f}\p{\xi} &= \int_\R e^{i\xi x}\p{f\p{x} - f\p{x - \frac{\pi}{\xi}}} \,\diff{x} \\ \implies \abs{\hat{f}\p{\xi}} &\leq \frac{1}{2} \norm{f - f\p{\:\cdot\: - \frac{\pi}{\xi}}}_{L^1}. \end{aligned}f^​(ξ)⟹2f^​(ξ)⟹∣∣​f^​(ξ)∣∣​​=−eπi∫R​eiξxf(x)dx=−∫R​eiξ(x+ξπ​)f(x)dx=−∫R​eiξxf(x−ξπ​)dx=∫R​eiξx(f(x)−f(x−ξπ​))dx≤21​∥∥​f−f(⋅−ξπ​)∥∥​L1​.​​(x↦x+ξπ​)​

    Notice that f(x)−f(x−πξ)→0f\p{x} - f\p{x - \frac{\pi}{\xi}} \to 0f(x)−f(x−ξπ​)→0 as ∣ξ∣→∞\abs{\xi} \to \infty∣ξ∣→∞, and ∣f(x)−f(x−πξ)∣≤∣f(x)∣+∣f(x−πξ)∣∈L1(R)\abs{f\p{x} - f\p{x - \frac{\pi}{\xi}}} \leq \abs{f\p{x}} + \abs{f\p{x - \frac{\pi}{\xi}}} \in L^1\p{\R}∣∣​f(x)−f(x−ξπ​)∣∣​≤∣f(x)∣+∣∣​f(x−ξπ​)∣∣​∈L1(R), so by dominated convergence, ∣f^(ξ)∣→0\abs{\hat{f}\p{\xi}} \to 0∣∣​f^​(ξ)∣∣​→0 as ∣ξ∣→∞\abs{\xi} \to \infty∣ξ∣→∞. Thus, f^∈C0(R)\hat{f} \in C_0\p{\R}f^​∈C0​(R).

  2. Cc∞(R)C_c^\infty\p{\R}Cc∞​(R) is dense in C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R) via convolutions against a smooth bump function. Thus, since Cc∞(R)C_c^\infty\p{\R}Cc∞​(R) are Schwartz functions, the Schwartz space is dense in C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R). Since the Fourier transform is a bijection on the Schwartz space, it follows that XXX contains the Schwartz space, hence dense in C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R).

  3. Let F ⁣:L1(R)→C0(R)\func{\mathcal{F}}{L^1\p{\R}}{C_0\p{\R}}F:L1(R)→C0​(R), f↦f^f \mapsto \hat{f}f↦f^​, where C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R) is equipped with the uniform norm. Then F\mathcal{F}F is a linear function between two Banach spaces. F\mathcal{F}F is an injective mapping, since it's essentially the Fourier transform, and it is continuous:

    ∣f^(ξ)−g^(ξ)∣≤∫R∣eiξx∣∣f(x)−g(x)∣ dx=∥f−g∥L1.\abs{\hat{f}\p{\xi} - \hat{g}\p{\xi}} \leq \int_\R \abs{e^{i\xi x}}\abs{f\p{x} - g\p{x}} \,\diff{x} = \norm{f - g}_{L^1}.∣∣​f^​(ξ)−g^​(ξ)∣∣​≤∫R​∣∣​eiξx∣∣​∣f(x)−g(x)∣dx=∥f−g∥L1​.

    Thus, if F\mathcal{F}F were surjective, then by the open mapping theorem, F\mathcal{F}F would be an open map, and it would have continuous inverse. To see why this is impossible, it suffices to find a sequence of functions {gn}n⊆C0(R)\set{g_n}_n \subseteq C_0\p{\R}{gn​}n​⊆C0​(R) such that gn=F(fn)g_n = \mathcal{F}\p{f_n}gn​=F(fn​) for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, {gn}n\set{g_n}_n{gn​}n​ is bounded in C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R), but {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is unbounded in L1(R)L^1\p{\R}L1(R).

    Let hn=χ[−n,n]h_n = \chi_{\br{-n, n}}hn​=χ[−n,n]​, and let gn=hn∗h1g_n = h_n * h_1gn​=hn​∗h1​. Observe that

    ∫Re−iξxhn(ξ) dξ=∫−nncos⁡ξx−isin⁡ξx dx=2sin⁡nxx,\int_\R e^{-i\xi x}h_n\p{\xi} \,\diff{\xi} = \int_{-n}^n \cos{\xi x} - i\sin{\xi x} \,\diff{x} = \frac{2\sin{nx}}{x},∫R​e−iξxhn​(ξ)dξ=∫−nn​cosξx−isinξxdx=x2sinnx​,

    and it follows via the inverse Fourier transform that

    F(4sin⁡nxsin⁡xx2)=F(2sin⁡nxx)∗F(2sin⁡xx)=hn∗h1=gn.\mathcal{F}\p{\frac{4\sin{nx}\sin{x}}{x^2}} = \mathcal{F}\p{\frac{2\sin{nx}}{x}} * \mathcal{F}\p{\frac{2\sin{x}}{x}} = h_n * h_1 = g_n.F(x24sinnxsinx​)=F(x2sinnx​)∗F(x2sinx​)=hn​∗h1​=gn​.

    Thus, gn∈C0(R)g_n \in C_0\p{\R}gn​∈C0​(R) and uniformly bounded via

    ∣gn(ξ)∣≤∥hn∥L∞∥h1∥L1≤2,\abs{g_n\p{\xi}} \leq \norm{h_n}_{L^\infty} \norm{h_1}_{L^1} \leq 2,∣gn​(ξ)∣≤∥hn​∥L∞​∥h1​∥L1​≤2,

    but

    ∥fn∥L1=∫R∣4sin⁡nxsin⁡xx2∣ dx≥4∫R∣sin⁡nxsin⁡xx2∣ dx=4n∫R∣sin⁡xsin⁡xnx2∣ dx(x↦nx)≥8nnπ∫0nπ/2∣sin⁡xx∣ dx(convexity of sin⁡x)=8π∫0nπ/2∣sin⁡xx∣ dx→n→∞∞.\begin{aligned} \norm{f_n}_{L^1} &= \int_\R \abs{\frac{4\sin{nx}\sin{x}}{x^2}} \,\diff{x} \\ &\geq 4 \int_\R \abs{\frac{\sin{nx}\sin{x}}{x^2}} \,\diff{x} \\ &= 4n \int_\R \abs{\frac{\sin{x}\sin{\frac{x}{n}}}{x^2}} \,\diff{x} && \p{x \mapsto nx} \\ &\geq \frac{8n}{n\pi} \int_0^{n\pi/2} \abs{\frac{\sin{x}}{x}} \,\diff{x} && (\text{convexity of } \sin{x}) \\ &= \frac{8}{\pi} \int_0^{n\pi/2} \abs{\frac{\sin{x}}{x}} \,\diff{x} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} \infty. \end{aligned}∥fn​∥L1​​=∫R​∣∣​x24sinnxsinx​∣∣​dx≥4∫R​∣∣​x2sinnxsinx​∣∣​dx=4n∫R​∣∣​x2sinxsinnx​​∣∣​dx≥nπ8n​∫0nπ/2​∣∣​xsinx​∣∣​dx=π8​∫0nπ/2​∣∣​xsinx​∣∣​dxn→∞​∞.​​(x↦nx)(convexity of sinx)​

    Hence, F−1\mathcal{F}^{-1}F−1 is unbounded on C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R), so F\mathcal{F}F cannot be surjective, and this completes the proof.
